"There is substantial evidence that genetic factors play a major role in determining a woman’s age at menopause. It is likely that this influence is exerted through an effect on ovarian reserve. One of the most frequently studied areas is the association between mothers’ and daughters’ ages at menopause. Since mothers and daughters share 50% of their genes, if age at menopause is affected by genetic factors, it is likely that a significant correlation would exist between mothers’ and daughters’ ages at menopause. Based on the research in this \u0020"
the heritability of menopausal age was 44%, which is quite significant in knowing the ovarian reserve levels.

Anti-Mullerian Hormone value is derived from undergoing a blood test. AMH is a natural protein that plays a major role in the development of the primary ovarian follicles. Research has shown that there is a significant correlation between serum AMH and the number of follicles in the ovaries. Therefore, it is an important part of the predictive measures of the ovarian reserve levels in humans. It is important to note that the AMH value peaks at approximately the age of 25.
Follicle-stimulating Hormone (FSH) is a hormone that stimulates the growth of egg follicles, therefore it plays a vital role in helping to determine the ovarian reserve.

"Ovarian volume is a calculation/measurement of the length, width, and depth of each of the ovaries. Medical studies have correlated ovarian size with a woman's ability to respond adequately to fertility medications."

"Antral-Follicle count (AFC) is a value that can be determined from a trans-vaginal ultrasound scan, it is the number of antral follicles on both ovaries. In determining the ovarian reserve level, AFC is a major determinant because is gives a fairly accurate number of eggs (oocytes) remaining in the ovaries."

"The cells that can become eggs are called non-growing follicles (NGFs for short). You were born with a fixed number of NGFs in your ovaries, this is your Ovarian Reserve. Typically there are about 400,000 in each ovary, but there is a large amount of variation so you could have been born with between 70,000 and 3 million NGFs.
There is a cycle that recruits some NGFs which grow into bigger and bigger follicles, but most of them die during the cycle. Only very few (about 400 for your whole reproductive lifespan) turn into eggs that can be fertilized.
It is believed that women who start with a high Ovarian Reserve lose NGFs quickly and women who have a low Ovarian Reserve lose NGFs slowly. This is because menopause happens for all women when there are about 1,000 NGFs left at an average age of 51 years.
This enables us to estimate the percentage of NGFs remaining for a woman of any age. The estimates are based on the Wallace-Kelsey model of NGF populations throughout life. Click on the link below to read the Science behind your results:\u0020"

"Smoking is linked to an earlier menopause, because in late reproductive age women at a given time, smokers are more likely to be menopausal than non-smokers. Research has shown that women who smoke more often than not reach the menopausal age earlier that non-smokers."
There is currently no concrete evidence that a high BMI will result in an adverse effect on the ovarian reserve.

This application sends no information about your answers to any server. Your results are calculated directly on your device. The individualised results generated by MyOvaries is based on works published by renowned Medical practitioners and accredited academic laureates.\u0020

However, they are not responsible for the individual choices regarding treatment that you make based on the results using MyOvaries. Patients should always discuss their options for treatment with trained clinicians.

Professor Hamish Wallace MD is the Muirhead Professor of Obstetrics and Gynaecology at the University of Edinburgh and an international expert in IVF.

"His research aims to understand and improve the health of women and their offspring throughout their reproductive life span. He is directly involved in looking after patients in Scotlan's two largest and most successful IVF units."
Dr Tom Kelsey is a Senior Lecturer at the University of Saint Andrews, and an international expert in mathematical models for biomedicine.
Tom, together with his student, were instrumental in developing the smartphone apps.
Mr Olalekan Baruwa is a MSc student at the University of Saint Andrews, and a software developer with a solid industrial experience in developing web and mobile applications.
Olalekan, worked on this project under the direct supervision of Dr Tom Kelsey.
